On Tue, Aug 5, 2008 at 5:32 AM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Derek, I also don't believe there has been a great deal of benchmark
> comparison sine the 2003 paper, although Alexandre Devert cites a
> few. However, usually when people attempt benchmarks they do not
> compare their results explicitly with others.
>
> At the same time, as you know, I have changed my philosophy somewhat
> since 2003 because I have realized that benchmark comparisons can
> lead to misunderstanding unless they are controlled very carefully.
> One of the problems is the "target-based evolution problem," which
> is one of the inspirations for novelty search. In short, evolving
> to an arbitrary target can lead to misleading intuitions about what
> is possible with a particular encoding because of deception. Often
> a "failed" encoding very well could represent the target if only it
> had been led to it through an alternative path through the search
> space.

But isn't that the general case of getting stuck in a particular part
of the solution space? If a particular candidate repeatedly fails to
represent very simple target patterns, such as rings and stars, and
complexifies to the point where it cannot revert back to a simpler
morphology, doesn't that say something about the AE system?

> Also, another problem with benchmarks is that they may obfuscate
> more fundamental advantages of particular approaches because they do
> not focus on general capabilities. (Although, of course, if you do
> enough of them, perhaps general capabilities start to be clearer.)
> But that is why I advocated more focus on looking for biological-
> like regularities in the patterns output by particular encodings,
> rather than looking for a single particular pattern, or even a
> single set of patterns.

Then how do you compare the representational capabilities of two AE
systems? For that matter, how do you go about determining the
representational capabilities of a single system?

It seems like the approach you're advocating is to evolve patterns
from a bunch of different starting points, with different
methodologies (e.g. artificial selection) and just see what shakes
out.

If I want to use a particular system to solve a particular problem,
and I know up front that particular types of patterns will be
extremely useful in solving the problem (e.g. bilateral symmetry),
wouldn't it make sense to explicitly test the system beforehand to see
how easily such patterns emerge and how stable they are once they do
emerge?

> Like I've said before, evolution never
> produced a wheel but that hardly means DNA is a bad encoding.

That's an interesting example. Do you think DNA has the
representational power to express a wheel, that it is
difficult/impossible to evolve a wheel via gradualism, and/or that
there hasn't been sufficient selection pressure in nature to produce a
wheel?

It seems to me that DNA certainly has the ability to express a wheel,
which is much simpler than many more complex designs that DNA does
express. I'd tend to think that wheels would not evolve on earth
because in general they would be maladaptive...the world isn't nice
and flat like a paved parking lot, and where it is (ice, desert),
rolling still wouldn't be as useful as walking, slithering, gliding,
or flying. I don't know, though...it's an interesting question.

In the environments in which Sims and others evolve "walkers", they
are flat. But the creatures are composed of cuboids (which could still
form wheels, albeit not very easily). If the representation included
objects like spheres or rings and primitives, or as patterns that
easily emerged, it would certainly be interesting to see if rolling
behavior evolved in favor of crawling or scooting across a flat
surface.

> Of course benchmarks can play a role and I do think more comparisons
> could be done, but we also have to be cautious about their misapplication.

As long as people aren't making strong claims about what a particular
system can't do, I don't see the problem. If a study was done where,
for example, three AE systems were compared for their ability to
evolve simple shapes such as stars, trees, and rings, various
symmetries, and simple controllers, I'd see nothing wrong with someone
stating that System A evolved solutions to certain problems more
quickly than the other systems, but less quickly in others. Just as
long as they're not saying, "System B failed to evolve a tree
structure, therefore System B is incapable of either representing or
evolving such a structure."

--Derek
